Banks don't care about our mental health. Their charity will not save us. We need community and collective care to confront the mental health impacts of the climate crisis. The biggest thing banks like @RBC can do to support youth mental health, is #divest from fossil fuels.

By funding fossil fuel expansion, banks bear a responsibility for the mental health impacts of the climate crisis. Banks will try to cover up their complicity by funding mental health initiatives, but we aren't fooled.

The mental health impacts of climate change are disproportionately felt by marginalized communities. Indigenous communities are one of the most impacted by climate anxiety and grief. We know that marginalized communities are also less likely to have access to mental healthcare.

Climate grief and climate anxiety are psychological responses to the climate crisis. These responses to climate change can feel isolating, but anxiety and grief are natural responses to the overwhelming violence of the climate crisis. You are not wrong or weak for feeling them.
The World Health Organization (WHO) has called the climate crisis "the greatest global health challenge of the 21st century." This crisis brings threats to our physical health and our mental health.

The climate crisis is harming our collective mental health. As young people especially, this crisis can feel overwhelming and even impossible to confront. Studies correlate an escalation in anxiety, depression and PTSD amongst young people with the climate crisis.
Climate change is a mental health issue, and banks like RBC are complicit. #bankingonabetterfuture

For Guilbeault to defer to The Market is disappointing. Design an Impact Assessment process that guides economic development; implement the Just Transition Act!;  Youth input; Indigenous rights and Free Prior & Informed Consent, end oil subsidies!! Let's go my man step it up.

All this to say, workers and communities are already facing effects of the energy transition and of the climate *crisis*. 
While The Market will adjust accordingly, it is literally the job of our new Environment Minister to guide this adjustment in a fair and just way.

This amounts, hopefully, to not only an eventual discouragement to stop building new pipelines due to better carbon prices, but also increasing delays mid construction so as to make them uneconomical in the first place (as with TMX).

And why would liquified natural gas (LNG) be any different? As a huge emitter of Methane, a highly dangerous source of GHGs, talk of natural gas as a "bridge fuel" amounts to simple greenwashing. Not to mention huge social opposition to new pipelines, led by Indigenous leaders.

In the energy sector, the market has long known that fossil fuels will have to wind down, or else risk becoming stranded assets in a burning planet. As the costliest and dirtiest source of energy, tarsands are first to the chopping block: https://t.co/66a5zjHJMl
